title: Simulation Verification of KS Confidence Band Coverage
text: band simultaneous (1‚àíŒ±)(1-\alpha) coverage P(supx|FÃÇn(x)‚àíF(x)|‚â§Œµn)‚â•1‚àíŒ±. P\!\left(\sup_{x} \lvert \hat{F}_n(x) - F(x) \rvert \leq \varepsilon_n\right) \;\geq\; 1 - \alpha. supremum equals Kolmogorov‚ÄìSmirnov statistic DnD_n, need P(Dn‚â§Œµn)‚â•1‚àíŒ±P(D_n \leq \varepsilon_n) \geq 1 - \alpha. FF continuous, DnD_n distribution-free null distribution, coverage depend true distribution.

title: Simulation Verification of KS Confidence Band Coverage
text: combination sample size nn nominal level 1‚àíŒ±1 - \alpha : Draw B=10,000B = 10{,}000 independent samples N(0,1)N(0, 1). Compute Dn=supx|FÃÇn(x)‚àíF(x)|D_n = \sup_x \lvert \hat{F}_n(x) - F(x) \rvert via ks.test(). Compute Œµn\varepsilon_n using formula geom_ecdf(). Record fraction replications Dn‚â§ŒµnD_n \leq \varepsilon_n.
code: set.seed(20240101)  B      <- 10000 ns     <- c(10, 20, 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000) levels <- c(0.90, 0.95, 0.99)  eps_fn <- function(n, level) sqrt(log(2 / (1 - level)) / (2 * n))  results <- do.call(rbind, lapply(ns, function(n) {   do.call(rbind, lapply(levels, function(lv) {     eps <- eps_fn(n, lv)     dn  <- replicate(B, ks.test(rnorm(n), "pnorm", exact = FALSE)$statistic)     data.frame(       n         = n,       level     = lv,       nominal   = lv,       empirical = mean(dn <= eps)     )   })) }))

title: Simulation Verification of KS Confidence Band Coverage
text: cell shows empirical coverage (‚â•\geq nominal). Empirical simultaneous coverage 10000 simulations N(0,1). Coverage always nominal level. bands slightly conservative small nn (DKW bound yet tight) approach nominal level nn grows.

title: Simulation Verification of KS Confidence Band Coverage
text: Empirical coverage (solid lines) lies dashed nominal line across nn. nn increases bands tighten toward nominal level, confirming DKW construction asymptotically exact.

title: Simulation Verification of KS Confidence Band Coverage
text: DnD_n continuous FF distribution-free, coverage holds continuous distribution. quick cross-check Uniform Exponential confirms : Coverage n = 100, level = 0.95 across distributions (B = 10000 sims). Coverage 95% distributions, confirming distribution-free guarantee.
code: set.seed(20240102)  n   <- 100 lv  <- 0.95 eps <- eps_fn(n, lv) B2  <- 10000  dists <- list(   Normal      = function() rnorm(n),   Uniform     = function() runif(n),   Exponential = function() rexp(n),   Beta        = function() rbeta(n, 2, 5) )  dist_results <- do.call(rbind, lapply(names(dists), function(nm) {   rfun   <- dists[[nm]]   # Use the corresponding theoretical CDF   pfun   <- switch(nm,     Normal      = function(x) pnorm(x),     Uniform     = function(x) punif(x),     Exponential = function(x) pexp(x),     Beta        = function(x) pbeta(x, 2, 5)   )   dn <- replicate(B2, {     x  <- sort(rfun())     fn <- seq_along(x) / n     # Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic: max over pre- and post-jump     max(c(abs(fn - pfun(x)), abs((seq_along(x) - 1) / n - pfun(x))))   })   data.frame(distribution = nm, empirical = mean(dn <= eps)) }))  dist_results$nominal <- paste0(lv * 100, "%") dist_results$empirical_pct <- paste0(round(dist_results$empirical * 100, 1), "%") knitr::kable(dist_results[, c("distribution", "nominal", "empirical_pct")],              col.names = c("Distribution", "Nominal", "Empirical"),              align = "lcc",              caption = paste0("Coverage at n = ", n, ", level = ", lv,                               " across distributions (B = ", B2, " sims)."))

title: Simulation Verification of KS Confidence Band Coverage
text: simulations confirm geom_ecdf() geom_eqf() produce valid simultaneous confidence bands: empirical coverage always nominal level, bands converge toward nominal level nn grows. DKW construction sound tested sample sizes distributions.

title: Gallery of Visualizations
text: lemniscate Bernoulli arrowhead tail marker:  Lissajous figures different frequency ratios:
code: lemniscate <- function(t) {   r <- sqrt(pmax(2 * cos(2 * t), 0))   c(r * cos(t), r * sin(t)) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(     fun = lemniscate, tlim = c(0, 1.9 * pi),     tail_point = TRUE,     arrow = grid::arrow(angle = 30, length = grid::unit(0.02, "npc"),                         type = "closed")   ) +   coord_equal() +   theme_void() make_lissajous <- function(a, b) {   function(t) c(sin(a * t), cos(b * t)) }  p1 <- ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(fun = make_lissajous(3, 2), tlim = c(0, 2 * pi)) +   coord_equal() + ggtitle("3:2") + theme_void()  p2 <- ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(fun = make_lissajous(5, 4), tlim = c(0, 2 * pi)) +   coord_equal() + ggtitle("5:4") + theme_void()  p3 <- ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(fun = make_lissajous(7, 6), tlim = c(0, 2 * pi)) +   coord_equal() + ggtitle("7:6") + theme_void()  p1 + p2 + p3

title: Gallery of Visualizations
text: PMF custom support ‚Äî distribution sample mean discrete uniform {0,0.5,1}\{0, 0.5, 1\} n=2n = 2:
code: mean_probs <- function(x) {   vals <- c(0, 0.5, 1)   grid <- expand.grid(x1 = vals, x2 = vals)   means <- rowMeans(grid)   tab <- table(means) / nrow(grid)   ifelse(as.character(x) %in% names(tab), as.numeric(tab[as.character(x)]), 0) }  ggplot() +   geom_pmf(fun = Vectorize(mean_probs), xlim = c(0, 1),            support = seq(0, 1, by = 0.25)) +   labs(title = "Sample mean distribution (n = 2)") +   theme_minimal()

title: Introduction to ggfunction
text: ggfunction extends ggplot2 visualize mathematical functions directly. provides unified interface organized around two families: geom_function_1d_1d(): ‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñù\mathbb{R} \\mathbb{R} (scalar scalar) geom_function_1d_2d(): ‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñù2\mathbb{R} \\mathbb{R}^2 (parametric curves) geom_function_2d_1d(): ‚Ñù2‚Üí‚Ñù\mathbb{R}^2 \\mathbb{R} (scalar fields, raster/contour) geom_function_2d_2d(): ‚Ñù2‚Üí‚Ñù2\mathbb{R}^2 \\mathbb{R}^2 (vector fields) geom_pdf(): probability density function geom_cdf(): cumulative distribution function geom_pmf(): probability mass function (lollipop) geom_qf(): quantile function geom_cdf_discrete(): discrete CDF (right-continuous step function) geom_qf_discrete(): discrete quantile function (left-continuous step function) geom_survival_discrete(): discrete survival function S(x)=1‚àíF(x)S(x) = 1 - F(x) (right-continuous step function) geom_survival(): survival function S(x)=1‚àíF(x)S(x) = 1 - F(x) geom_hf(): hazard function h(x)=f(x)/S(x)h(x) = f(x)/S(x)

title: Learning Statistics with ggfunction
text: probability density function (PDF) describes relative likelihood continuous random variable taking given value. area curve interval equals probability falling interval. standard normal, P(‚àí1<X<1)‚âà0.68P(-1 < X < 1) \approx 0.68:
code: ggplot() +   geom_pdf(fun = dnorm, xlim = c(-4, 4),            p_lower = pnorm(-1), p_upper = pnorm(1),            fill = "steelblue") +   labs(title = "Standard Normal Density",        subtitle = "P(-1 < X < 1) \u2248 0.68",        x = "x", y = "Density") +   theme_minimal()

title: Learning Statistics with ggfunction
text: cumulative distribution function (CDF) F(x)=P(X‚â§x)F(x) = P(X \le x) running area PDF ‚àí‚àû-\infty xx. Notice CDF‚Äôs steepest climb corresponds PDF tallest:
code: p1 <- ggplot() +   geom_pdf(fun = dnorm, xlim = c(-4, 4), fill = "steelblue",            p = 0.8) +   labs(title = "PDF", x = "x", y = "f(x)") +   theme_minimal()  p2 <- ggplot() +   geom_cdf(fun = pnorm, xlim = c(-4, 4), p = 0.8,            fill = "steelblue") +   labs(title = "CDF", x = "x", y = "F(x)") +   theme_minimal()  p1 + p2

title: Learning Statistics with ggfunction
text: quantile function Q(p)=F‚àí1(p)Q(p) = F^{-1}(p) answers inverse question: given probability pp, value xx satisfies F(x)=pF(x) = p? median 50th percentile ‚Äî Q(0.5)Q(0.5):
code: ggplot() +   geom_qf(fun = qnorm, args = list(mean = 0, sd = 1)) +   geom_vline(xintercept = 0.5, linetype = "dashed", color = "darkgreen") +   geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "darkgreen") +   labs(title = "Standard Normal Quantile Function",        subtitle = "Median at Q(0.5) = 0",        x = "p", y = "Q(p)") +   theme_minimal()

title: Learning Statistics with ggfunction
text: two-sided test significance level Œ±=0.05\alpha = 0.05, reject H0H_0 test statistic falls tails beyond ¬±z0.025‚âà¬±1.96\pm z_{0.025} \approx \pm 1.96. shaded rejection region captures extreme 5% null distribution:
code: ggplot() +   geom_pdf(     fun = dnorm, xlim = c(-4, 4),     p_lower = 0.025, p_upper = 0.975,     shade_outside = TRUE, fill = "firebrick"   ) +   labs(     title = "Two-Sided Rejection Region",     subtitle = expression(alpha == 0.05 ~ ": reject" ~ H[0] ~ "in shaded tails"),     x = "Test statistic (z)", y = "Density"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Learning Statistics with ggfunction
text: 95% confidence interval mean normal distribution corresponds central 95% sampling distribution. shaded region shows values rejected two-sided test:
code: ggplot() +   geom_pdf(     fun = dnorm, xlim = c(-4, 4),     p_lower = 0.025, p_upper = 0.975,     fill = "steelblue"   ) +   labs(     title = "Central 95% Interval",     subtitle = expression("Between" ~ z[0.025] == -1.96 ~ "and" ~ z[0.975] == 1.96),     x = "x", y = "Density"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Learning Statistics with ggfunction
text: Generate sample N(0,1)N(0, 1) overlay empirical CDF theoretical CDF. KS confidence band (shown automatically geom_ecdf()) helps assess whether data consistent theoretical model:
code: set.seed(2024) df <- data.frame(x = rnorm(40))  ggplot(df, aes(x = x)) +   geom_ecdf(color = "steelblue") +   geom_cdf(fun = pnorm, xlim = c(-3.5, 3.5),            color = "firebrick", linewidth = 0.8) +   labs(     title = "Empirical vs. Theoretical CDF",     subtitle = "Blue = ECDF with 95% KS band, Red = N(0, 1)",     x = "x", y = "F(x)"   ) +   theme_minimal()

title: Learning Statistics with ggfunction
text: survival function S(x)=1‚àíF(x)=P(X>x)S(x) = 1 - F(x) = P(X > x) gives probability surviving past time xx. hazard function h(x)=f(x)/S(x)h(x) = f(x) / S(x) instantaneous failure rate. exponential distribution constant hazard ‚Äî memory aging. Weibull distribution allows increasing decreasing hazard depending shape parameter:  Blue = Exponential (constant hazard), Red = Weibull shape 2 (increasing), Green = Weibull shape 0.5 (decreasing).
code: p1 <- ggplot() +   geom_survival(fun = pexp, xlim = c(0, 6),                 args = list(rate = 0.5), color = "steelblue") +   geom_survival(fun = pweibull, xlim = c(0, 6),                 args = list(shape = 2, scale = 2), color = "firebrick") +   geom_survival(fun = pweibull, xlim = c(0, 6),                 args = list(shape = 0.5, scale = 2), color = "forestgreen") +   labs(title = "Survival Functions", x = "t", y = "S(t)") +   theme_minimal()  p2 <- ggplot() +   geom_hf(pdf_fun = dexp, cdf_fun = pexp, xlim = c(0.01, 6),            args = list(rate = 0.5), color = "steelblue") +   geom_hf(pdf_fun = dweibull, cdf_fun = pweibull, xlim = c(0.01, 6),            args = list(shape = 2, scale = 2), color = "firebrick") +   geom_hf(pdf_fun = dweibull, cdf_fun = pweibull, xlim = c(0.01, 6),            args = list(shape = 0.5, scale = 2), color = "forestgreen") +   labs(title = "Hazard Functions", x = "t", y = "h(t)") +   coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 3)) +   theme_minimal()  p1 + p2

title: Learning Statistics with ggfunction
text: skewed multimodal distributions, equal-tailed intervals waste coverage low-density areas. highest density region (HDR) always captures probable values given coverage level. Compare HDR equal-tailed interval right-skewed mixture:  HDR concentrates coverage high-density peak, equal-tailed interval extends far sparse right tail.
code: skewed <- function(x) 0.7 * dnorm(x, 2, 0.8) + 0.3 * dnorm(x, 5, 1.5)  p1 <- ggplot() +   geom_pdf(fun = skewed, xlim = c(-2, 10), shade_hdr = 0.9,            fill = "orchid") +   labs(title = "90% HDR", subtitle = "Shortest interval(s) covering 90%") +   theme_minimal()  # For comparison: equal-tailed 90% # Find quantiles by numerical inversion skewed_cdf <- function(x) {   0.7 * pnorm(x, 2, 0.8) + 0.3 * pnorm(x, 5, 1.5) } q_lower <- uniroot(function(x) skewed_cdf(x) - 0.05, c(-5, 10))$root q_upper <- uniroot(function(x) skewed_cdf(x) - 0.95, c(-5, 10))$root  p2 <- ggplot() +   geom_pdf(fun = skewed, xlim = c(-2, 10),            p_lower = 0.05, p_upper = 0.95,            fill = "steelblue") +   labs(title = "90% Equal-Tailed Interval",        subtitle = "Wastes coverage in the right tail") +   theme_minimal()  p1 + p2

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: ggfunction extends ggplot2 geoms stats plotting mathematical functions probability distributions directly function objects. Supply function domain; ggfunction handles evaluation, rendering, shading.

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: package organized around two families geoms:

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_function_1d_1d() evaluates function f:‚Ñù‚Üí‚Ñùf\colon \mathbb{R} \\mathbb{R} n equally-spaced points xlim draws curve, extending ggplot2::stat_function() built-region shading. following example plots sine function one full period.  Shading intervals. shade_from shade_to parameters fill region curve xx-axis specified interval. shade standard normal density ‚àí1-1 11, corresponding approximately 68% total area.
code: library("ggfunction")  ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_1d(fun = sin, xlim = c(0, 2*pi)) ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_1d(fun = sin, xlim = c(-3, 3), shade_from = -1, shade_to = 1)

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_function_1d_2d() evaluates parametric curve ùõÑ(t)=(x(t),y(t))\boldsymbol{\gamma}(t) = (x(t),\, y(t)) range tlim step size dt, coloring path time parameter default. following example traces lemniscate Bernoulli ‚Äì figure-eight curve along product distances two foci constant ‚Äì ùõÑ(t)=(cost/(1+sin2t),sintcost/(1+sin2t))\boldsymbol{\gamma}(t) = \bigl(\cos t\,/\,(1 + \sin^2 t),\; \sin t\cos t\,/\,(1 + \sin^2 t)\bigr).  Arrowheads tail points. Setting tail_point = TRUE passing grid::arrow() arrow marks starting position curve point tail arrowhead, respectively, useful showing initial condition direction curve.  Parameterized families. Extra parameters fun passed via args. following example traces Lissajous figure, closed curve results two sinusoids rational frequency ratio combined.
code: lemniscate <- function(t) c(cos(t) / (1 + sin(t)^2), sin(t) * cos(t) / (1 + sin(t)^2))  ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(fun = lemniscate, tlim = c(0, 1.9 * pi)) ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(     fun = lemniscate, tlim = c(0, 1.9 * pi), tail_point = TRUE,     arrow = grid::arrow(angle = 30, length = grid::unit(0.02, "npc"), type = "closed")   ) lissajous <- function(t, a = 3, b = 2, delta = pi/2) {   c(sin(a * t + delta), sin(b * t)) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(     fun = lissajous, tlim = c(0, 1.9 * pi),     args = list(a = 3, b = 2, delta = pi/2)   )

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_function_2d_1d() evaluates scalar field f:‚Ñù2‚Üí‚Ñùf\colon \mathbb{R}^2 \\mathbb{R} n√ónn \times n grid xlim √ó\timesylim. function must accept numeric vector length 2 return scalar; extracting components x <- v[1]; y <- v[2] recommended pattern. example shows Gaussian bump f(x,y)=exp(‚àí(x2+y2)/2)f(x,y) = \exp\!\bigl(-(x^2+y^2)/2\bigr) rendered raster heatmap (default type).  Contour modes. type argument switches among three visual encodings field. "contour" draws iso-level curves colored level value; "contour_filled" draws filled regions levels; respond bins, binwidth, breaks.
code: f <- function(v) {   x <- v[1]; y <- v[2]   sin(2*pi*x) + sin(2*pi*y) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_1d(fun = f, xlim = c(-1, 1), ylim = c(-1, 1)) ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_1d(fun = f, xlim = c(-1, 1), ylim = c(-1, 1), type = "contour") ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_1d(fun = f, xlim = c(-1, 1), ylim = c(-1, 1), type = "contour_filled")

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_function_2d_2d() visualizes vector field ùêÖ:‚Ñù2‚Üí‚Ñù2\mathbf{F}\colon \mathbb{R}^2 \\mathbb{R}^2 via ggvfields. function accept length-2 vector return length-2 vector. default (type = "vector") draws short arrows grid point colored field magnitude; type = "stream" switches integral-curve streamlines. following example shows rotation field ùêÖ(x,y)=(‚àíy,x)\mathbf{F}(x,y) = (-y,\, x).  Stream field. Setting type = "stream" renders field integral curves computed numerical integration, colored average speed along curve.
code: f <- function(u) {   x <- u[1]; y <- u[2]   c(-y, x) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_2d(fun = f, xlim = c(-1, 1), ylim = c(-1, 1)) ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_2d(fun = f, xlim = c(-1, 1), ylim = c(-1, 1), type = "stream")

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: probability family provides geom standard functions associated distribution. accepts plain R function (e.g.¬†dnorm, pnorm) xlim; distribution parameters passed via args.

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_pdf() draws probability density function filled area. validates supplied function integrates 1 xlim, warning via cli . basic call draws full density shading.  Single threshold. p parameter shades left boundary pp-quantile (lower.tail = TRUE, default). Setting lower.tail = FALSE shades upper tail instead. shade lower 97.5%.  Two-sided interval. p_lower p_upper together shade central region two quantiles‚Äînatural picture confidence interval. following example shades central 95%.  Tail shading. Setting shade_outside = TRUE inverts two-sided region, shading tails. rejection region two-sided hypothesis test level Œ±=0.05\alpha = 0.05.  Highest density region. shade_hdr shades smallest region domain containing specified probability mass‚Äîhighest density region (HDR). multimodal densities region can disconnected. following example uses asymmetric mixture two normals; 80% HDR captures modes two disjoint intervals, area allocated taller, narrower component.
code: ggplot() +   geom_pdf(fun = dnorm, xlim = c(-3, 3)) ggplot() +   geom_pdf(fun = dnorm, xlim = c(-3, 3), p = 0.975) ggplot() +   geom_pdf(fun = dnorm, xlim = c(-3, 3), p_lower = 0.025, p_upper = 0.975) ggplot() +   geom_pdf(     fun = dnorm, xlim = c(-3, 3),     p_lower = 0.025, p_upper = 0.975, shade_outside = TRUE   ) f_mix <- function(x) 0.6 * dnorm(x, mean = -2, sd = 0.6) + 0.4 * dnorm(x, mean = 2, sd = 1.2) ggplot() +   geom_pdf(fun = f_mix, xlim = c(-5, 6), shade_hdr = 0.8)

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_pmf() evaluates probability mass function integer xlim renders result lollipop chart‚Äîvertical segments capped points. Distribution parameters supplied via args. following example plots Binomial(10,0.3)\text{Binomial}(10, 0.3) distribution.  Single threshold. p parameter shades lollipops pp-quantile (grey dashed sticks mark unshaded region). shade lower 80% Binomial(10,0.5)\text{Binomial}(10, 0.5) distribution.  Highest density region. shade_hdr shades smallest set support points whose total probability mass meets exceeds target coverage. symmetric unimodal PMF central interval; skewed distribution asymmetric. 70% HDR Binomial(10,0.3)\text{Binomial}(10, 0.3) distribution highlighted.   Explicit support. support sequence consecutive integers, pass exact support points via support. plot distribution sample mean X‚Äæ\bar X 10 iid Bernoulli(0.3)\text{Bernoulli}(0.3) draws. support {0,0.1,0.2,‚Ä¶,1}\{0, 0.1, 0.2, \ldots, 1\} PMF binomial: P(X‚Äæ=k/10)=(10k)0.3k0.710‚àíkP(\bar X = k/10) = \binom{10}{k}0.3^k 0.7^{10-k}.
code: ggplot() +   geom_pmf(fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.3)) ggplot() +   geom_pmf(fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5), p = 0.8) ggplot() +   geom_pmf(fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.3),     shade_hdr = .70) ggplot() +   geom_pmf(fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.3),     shade_hdr = .80) f_mean <- function(x, prob) dbinom(round(x * 10), size = 10, prob = prob) ggplot() +   geom_pmf(fun = f_mean, support = seq(0, 1, by = 0.1), args = list(prob = 0.3))

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: cumulative distribution function F(x)=P(X‚â§x)F(x) = P(X \le x) available continuous discrete distributions. Continuous (geom_cdf()). Draws CDF line. plot standard normal CDF.  Discrete (geom_cdf_discrete()). Takes PMF, accumulates right-continuous step-function CDF, renders horizontal segments, dashed vertical jumps, open circles lower limit jump, closed circles achieved value. following example plots Binomial(10,0.5)\text{Binomial}(10, 0.5) CDF.  Parameterized families. plot Poisson(5)\text{Poisson}(5) discrete CDF.  Hiding points lines. show_points = FALSE show_vert = FALSE remove endpoint circles vertical jump segments, leaving horizontal staircase.  Explicit support. Pass non-integer support points directly via support. plot CDF sample mean 10 iid Bernoulli(0.3)\text{Bernoulli}(0.3) draws.
code: ggplot() +   geom_cdf(fun = pnorm, xlim = c(-3, 3)) ggplot() +   geom_cdf_discrete(pmf_fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5)) ggplot() +   geom_cdf_discrete(pmf_fun = dpois, xlim = c(0, 15), args = list(lambda = 5)) ggplot() +   geom_cdf_discrete(pmf_fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5),     show_points = FALSE, show_vert = FALSE) f_mean <- function(x, prob) dbinom(round(x * 10), size = 10, prob = prob) ggplot() +   geom_cdf_discrete(pmf_fun = f_mean, support = seq(0, 1, by = 0.1), args = list(prob = 0.3))

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: survival function S(x)=1‚àíF(x)=P(X>x)S(x) = 1 - F(x) = P(X > x) gives probability surviving past xx. Continuous (geom_survival()). Accepts CDF via fun. following example shows survival function Exponential(0.5)\text{Exponential}(0.5) distribution, decays S(x)=e‚àí0.5xS(x) = e^{-0.5x}.  Discrete (geom_survival_discrete()). Takes PMF renders S(x)=1‚àíF(x)S(x) = 1 - F(x) right-continuous step function using visual conventions geom_cdf_discrete(). following example plots Binomial(10,0.5)\text{Binomial}(10, 0.5) survival function.  Hiding points. Setting show_points = FALSE removes endpoint circles.  Explicit support. survival function sample mean 10 iid Bernoulli(0.3)\text{Bernoulli}(0.3) draws.
code: ggplot() +   geom_survival(fun = pexp, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(rate = 0.5)) ggplot() +   geom_survival_discrete(pmf_fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5)) ggplot() +   geom_survival_discrete(pmf_fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5),     show_points = FALSE) f_mean <- function(x, prob) dbinom(round(x * 10), size = 10, prob = prob) ggplot() +   geom_survival_discrete(pmf_fun = f_mean, support = seq(0, 1, by = 0.1), args = list(prob = 0.3))

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: quantile function Q(p)=inf{x:F(x)‚â•p}Q(p) = \inf\{x : F(x) \ge p\} inverts CDF. Continuous (geom_qf()). Evaluates quantile function unit interval (0,1)(0, 1) draws curve. following example plots standard normal quantile function.  Discrete (geom_qf_discrete()). Takes PMF renders quantile function left-continuous step function unit interval, closed circles bottom jump (value achieved) open circles top (next value yet reached). following example plots Binomial(10,0.5)\text{Binomial}(10, 0.5) quantile function.  Parameterized families. plot Poisson(5)\text{Poisson}(5) discrete quantile function.  Hiding points. Setting show_points = FALSE removes endpoint circles, leaving horizontal vertical lines.  Hiding vertical lines. Setting show_vert = FALSE removes dashed vertical jump segments, leaving horizontal steps endpoint circles.  Explicit support. quantile function sample mean 10 iid Bernoulli(0.3)\text{Bernoulli}(0.3) draws.
code: ggplot() +   geom_qf(fun = qnorm) ggplot() +   geom_qf_discrete(pmf_fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5)) ggplot() +   geom_qf_discrete(pmf_fun = dpois, xlim = c(0, 15), args = list(lambda = 5)) ggplot() +   geom_qf_discrete(pmf_fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5),     show_points = FALSE) ggplot() +   geom_qf_discrete(pmf_fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5),     show_vert = FALSE) f_mean <- function(x, prob) dbinom(round(x * 10), size = 10, prob = prob) ggplot() +   geom_qf_discrete(pmf_fun = f_mean, support = seq(0, 1, by = 0.1), args = list(prob = 0.3))

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_hf() plots hazard function h(x)=f(x)/S(x)h(x) = f(x) / S(x), instantaneous rate failure time xx conditional survival point. requires PDF (pdf_fun) CDF (cdf_fun). Shared parameters go args; use pdf_args cdf_args overrides two functions different parameterizations. exponential distribution‚Äôs constant hazard confirms memoryless property.
code: ggplot() +   geom_hf(pdf_fun = dexp, cdf_fun = pexp, xlim = c(0.01, 10), args = list(rate = 0.5))

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: data family works observed numeric sample rather function object. Supply vector data via aes(x = ...) geom handles rest. three geoms use visual language theoretical counterparts Probability section.

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_ecdf() plots empirical cumulative distribution function sample right-continuous step function, using visual conventions geom_cdf_discrete(). 95% simultaneous Kolmogorov-Smirnov confidence ribbon drawn default; set conf_int = FALSE suppress .  Multiple groups. Map colour grouping variable overlay ECDFs several groups. group gets confidence ribbon, computed group‚Äôs sample size.  Controlling band. Use level change confidence level conf_alpha adjust ribbon transparency.
code: ggplot(df_single, aes(x = x)) +   geom_ecdf() ggplot(df_two, aes(x = x, colour = group)) +   geom_ecdf() ggplot(df_single, aes(x = x)) +   geom_ecdf(level = 0.99, conf_alpha = 0.15)

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_eqf() plots empirical quantile function Qn(p)=inf{x:FÃÇn(x)‚â•p}Q_n(p) = \inf\{x : \hat{F}_n(x) \ge p\} left-continuous step function [0,1][0, 1], using visual conventions geom_qf_discrete(). confidence ribbon inverts KS ECDF band: probability pp band spans [Qn(p‚àíŒµ),Qn(p+Œµ)][Q_n(p - \varepsilon), Q_n(p + \varepsilon)].  Multiple groups.  Informal normality test. KS confidence band covers true quantile function Q(p)Q(p) probability ‚â•1‚àíŒ±\ge 1 - \alpha regardless null, overlaying parametric Q0(p)Q_0(p) turns plot visual goodness--fit test: Q0Q_0 lies entirely within band data consistent hypothesized model; exits band evidence . comparison fits normal distribution maximum likelihood (sample mean SD) two samples size n=100n = 100‚Äîone actually normal, one exponential‚Äîoverlays fitted Q0Q_0 smooth line.  fitted normal line threads center band normal sample; exponential sample departs visibly tails, asymmetry exponential distribution pronounced. Note estimating parameters data makes band slightly conservative (analogous Lilliefors correction), informal rather exact test.
code: ggplot(df_single, aes(x = x)) +   geom_eqf() ggplot(df_two, aes(x = x, color = group)) +   geom_eqf() library(patchwork) set.seed(3)  normal_qf <- function(p, x) qnorm(p, mean = mean(x), sd = sd(x))  df_normal <- data.frame(x = rnorm(100)) p_norm <- ggplot(df_normal, aes(x = x)) +   geom_eqf() +   geom_qf(fun = normal_qf, args = list(x = df_normal$x), colour = "red") +   ggtitle("Normal data")  df_exp <- data.frame(x = rexp(100) - 1) p_exp <- ggplot(df_exp, aes(x = x)) +   geom_eqf() +   geom_qf(fun = normal_qf, args = list(x = df_exp$x), colour = "red") +   ggtitle("Exponential data")  p_norm | p_exp

title: Extending ggplot2 with functional capabilities
text: geom_epmf() tabulates empirical probability mass function‚Äîplacing mass ck/nc_k / n distinct observed value xkx_k‚Äîrenders lollipop chart using visual conventions geom_pmf().  Multiple groups.
code: ggplot(df_single, aes(x = x)) +   geom_epmf() ggplot(df_two, aes(x = x, colour = group)) +   geom_epmf()

title: Plot a Cumulative Distribution Function ‚Äî geom_cdf
text: geom_cdf() creates ggplot2 layer plots cumulative distribution function (CDF) line. can optionally shade region specifying cumulative probability threshold via p, two-sided interval via p_lower p_upper.

title: Plot a Cumulative Distribution Function ‚Äî geom_cdf
code: geom_cdf(   mapping = NULL,   data = NULL,   stat = StatCDF,   position = "identity",   ...,   na.rm = FALSE,   show.legend = NA,   inherit.aes = FALSE,   fun,   xlim = NULL,   n = 101,   args = list(),   fill = "grey20",   color = "black",   p = NULL,   lower.tail = TRUE,   p_lower = NULL,   p_upper = NULL )  StatCDF  GeomCDF

what: Plot an Empirical Cumulative Distribution Function ‚Äî geom_ecdf
title: Plot an Empirical Cumulative Distribution Function ‚Äî geom_ecdf
text: geom_ecdf() computes empirical CDF sample renders right-continuous step function, using visual conventions geom_cdf_discrete(): horizontal segments, dashed vertical jumps, open circles left limit jump, closed circles achieved value. optional simultaneous confidence band (defaulting 95%) drawn around step function using Kolmogorov-Smirnov construction.

title: Plot an Empirical Cumulative Distribution Function ‚Äî geom_ecdf
text: empirical distribution places mass \(c_k / n\) distinct observed value \(x_k\), \(c_k\) count occurrences \(n\) total sample size. Ties handled correctly. simultaneous confidence band inverts Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. half-width \(\varepsilon = \sqrt{\log(2/\alpha) / (2n)}\), \(\alpha = 1 - \texttt{level}\), giving pointwise bounds \([\hat{F}_n(x) - \varepsilon,\, \hat{F}_n(x) + \varepsilon]\) clipped \([0, 1]\).

title: Plot an Empirical Quantile Function ‚Äî geom_eqf
text: empirical quantile function left-continuous inverse empirical CDF: \(Q(p) = \inf\{x : F_n(x) \geq p\}\). confidence band probability level \(p\) \([Q_n(p - \varepsilon),\, Q_n(p + \varepsilon)]\), \(\varepsilon = \sqrt{\log(2/\alpha) / (2n)}\) KS half-width (\(\alpha = 1 - \texttt{level}\)). follows directly inverting simultaneous ECDF confidence band.

text: functions provide convenient ggplot2 layers drawing streams generated mapping one-dimensional input (typically time) two-dimensional coordinates. user-defined function (fun) specifies mapping taking numeric scalar (e.g. time) returning numeric vector length 2 (representing \((x, y)\)). underlying Stat_1d_2d evaluates fun time sequence spanning tlim increments dt, ggvfields::GeomStream renders resulting path.

title: 1D-to-2D Function Stream Plot for ggplot2 ‚Äî geom_function_1d_2d
text: mapping set aesthetic mappings created ggplot2::aes(). Additional aesthetics color, size, linetype, alpha can defined. default mapping sets color = after_stat(t). data data frame containing input data. many cases, data needs supplied. position Position adjustment, either string result call position adjustment function. ... arguments passed ggplot2::layer(). na.rm Logical. FALSE (default), missing values removed warning. show.legend Logical. layer included legends? inherit.aes Logical. FALSE, overrides default aesthetics rather combining . fun function defines mapping scalar input (typically time) two-dimensional coordinate. take numeric scalar return numeric vector length 2 representing \((x, y)\). (Required) tlim Numeric vector length 2. range time sequence, given c(t_start, t_end). Defaults c(0, 10). dt Numeric. time increment evaluating fun. Defaults 0.01. args List additional arguments passed function defined fun. tail_point Logical. TRUE, point drawn tail (starting position) stream. arrow grid::arrow() specification add arrowheads stream. Defaults NULL (arrowhead). Pass grid::arrow() add one. stat statistical transformation use data layer. Defaults Stat_1d_2d.

code: f <- function(t) {   c(sin(t), cos(t)) }  ggplot() + geom_function_1d_2d(fun = f)   f <- function(t) {   c(sin(t), t * cos(t)) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(fun = f, tlim = c(0, 20), tail_point = TRUE)   f <- function(t) {   x <- sin(t) * (exp(cos(t)) - 2 * cos(4 * t) - (sin(t / 12))^5)   y <- cos(t) * (exp(cos(t)) - 2 * cos(4 * t) - (sin(t / 12))^5)   c(x, y) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(fun = f, tlim = c(0, 6.5), arrow = NULL, color = "black")   f <- function(t)  c(abs(cos(t)*t), t)  ggplot() + geom_function_1d_2d(fun = f, tlim = c(-20, 20))   # Lissajous curve lissajous <- function(t, A = 1, B = 1, a = 3, b = 2, delta = pi/2) {   c(A * sin(a * t + delta), B * sin(b * t)) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(     fun = lissajous, tlim = c(0, 2 * pi), color = "black", arrow = NULL,     args = list(A = 1, B = 1, a = 3, b = 2, delta = pi/2)   )   # Variations on Lissajous curves ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(     fun = lissajous, tlim = c(0, 2 * pi), color = "black", arrow = NULL,     args = list(A = 2, B = 1, a = 4, b = 2, delta = pi/4)   )   ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(     fun = lissajous, tlim = c(0, 2 * pi), color = "black", arrow = NULL,     args = list(A = 1, B = 2, a = 5, b = 3, delta = pi/3)   )   ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(     fun = lissajous, tlim = c(0, 2 * pi), color = "black", arrow = NULL,     args = list(A = 0.5, B = 0.5, a = 2, b = 3, delta = pi/6)   )   ggplot() +   geom_function_1d_2d(     fun = lissajous, tlim = c(0, 2 * pi), color = "black", arrow = NULL,     args = list(A = 0.5, B = 0.5, a = 5, b = 4, delta = pi/2)   )   # Harmonic cuves  f <- function(t,   A1 = 1, A2 = 1, A3 = 1, A4 = 1,   f1 = 1, f2 = 2, f3 = 3, f4 = 4,   p1 = 0, p2 = pi/4, p3 = pi/2, p4 = 3*pi/4,   d1 = 0.1, d2 = 0.2, d3 = 0.3, d4 = 0.4) {     x <- A1 * sin(t * f1 + p1) * exp(-d1 * t) + A2 * sin(t * f2 + p2) * exp(-d2 * t)     y <- A3 * sin(t * f3 + p3) * exp(-d3 * t) + A4 * sin(t * f4 + p4) * exp(-d4 * t)     c(x, y) }  ggplot() + geom_function_1d_2d(fun = f, tlim = c(0, 5))

code: # Function that calculates the norm f <- function(v) {   x <- v[1]   y <- v[2]   c(sqrt(x^2 + y^2)) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_1d(fun = f, xlim = c(-5, 5), ylim = c(-5, 5))   # Sinusoidal combination of sine and cosine f_sin_cos <- function(v) {   x <- v[1]   y <- v[2]   sin(x) * cos(y) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_1d(fun = f_sin_cos, xlim = c(-5, 5), ylim = c(-5, 5))   # Gaussian bump function f_gaussian <- function(v) {   x <- v[1]   y <- v[2]   exp(-(x^2 + y^2) / 2) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_1d(fun = f_gaussian, xlim = c(-5, 5), ylim = c(-5, 5))   # Radial sine wave function f_radial_wave <- function(v) {   x <- v[1]   y <- v[2]   r <- sqrt(x^2 + y^2)   sin(r) }  # Some functions need more resolution for clarity ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_1d(fun = f_radial_wave, xlim = c(-50, 50), ylim = c(-50, 50), n = 100)   # Complex combination of radial and angular components f_complex <- function(v) {   x <- v[1]   y <- v[2]   r <- sqrt(x^2 + y^2)   theta <- atan2(y, x)   sin(r) * cos(theta) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_1d(fun = f_complex, xlim = c(-50, 50), ylim = c(-50, 50), n = 500)   # Spiral pattern function f_spiral <- function(v) {   x <- v[1]   y <- v[2]   r <- sqrt(x^2 + y^2)   theta <- atan2(y, x)   sin(r + theta) }  ggplot() +   geom_function_2d_1d(fun = f_spiral, xlim = c(-50, 50), ylim = c(-50, 50), n = 500)

title: Plot a Hazard Function h(x) = f(x) / S(x) ‚Äî geom_hf
text: PDF + CDF interface: supply pdf_fun cdf_fun; hazard computed internally \(h(x) = f(x) / (1 - F(x))\). Direct hazard interface: supply fun, function returns \(h(x)\) directly (e.g. closed-form expression). Exactly one two interfaces must used. default line drawn (fill).

title: Plot a Hazard Function h(x) = f(x) / S(x) ‚Äî geom_hf
code: # PDF + CDF interface   ggplot() +     geom_hf(pdf_fun = dnorm, cdf_fun = pnorm, xlim = c(-3, 3))     ggplot() +     geom_hf(pdf_fun = dexp, cdf_fun = pexp,       args = list(rate = 0.5), xlim = c(0, 10))     # Direct hazard interface (Weibull closed-form hazard)   h_weibull <- function(x, shape, scale) (shape / scale) * (x / scale)^(shape - 1)   ggplot() +     geom_hf(fun = h_weibull, xlim = c(0.01, 5),       args = list(shape = 0.5, scale = 2))

text: geom_pmf() creates ggplot2 layer plots probability mass function (PMF) using lollipop representation. Vertical segments extend zero probability value integer support value point drawn top. code: # Basic PMF ggplot() +   geom_pmf(fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.25))   # Shade the lower tail up to the 80th percentile ggplot() +   geom_pmf(fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5),     p = 0.8)   # Shade the 80% HDR ggplot() +   geom_pmf(fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5),     shade_hdr = 0.8) #> ! shade_hdr: 80% is not exactly achievable for this discrete distribution. #> ‚Ñπ Using smallest HDR with coverage >= 80%: actual coverage = 89.1%.

text: geom_survival_discrete() renders discrete survival function \(S(x) = 1 - F(x)\) right-continuous step function horizontal segments, dashed vertical jumps, open circles lower limit jump, closed circles upper limit.

title: Plot a Discrete Survival Function as a Step Function ‚Äî geom_survival_discrete
text: ggplot2 layer.

title: Plot a Discrete Survival Function as a Step Function ‚Äî geom_survival_discrete
text: Supply either pmf_fun (PMF dbinom, CDF computed via cumulative summation) fun (CDF pbinom, \(S(x) = 1 - F(x)\) computed directly).

title: Plot a Discrete Survival Function as a Step Function ‚Äî geom_survival_discrete
code: # via PMF   ggplot() +     geom_survival_discrete(pmf_fun = dbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5))     # via CDF directly   ggplot() +     geom_survival_discrete(fun = pbinom, xlim = c(0, 10), args = list(size = 10, prob = 0.5))     ggplot() +     geom_survival_discrete(pmf_fun = dpois, xlim = c(0, 15), args = list(lambda = 5))
